author: Graham Dyson
description: Eunice helps improve software architecture by analyzing, measuring, exploring and defining; structure and dependencies. Eunice is based on the premise that software structure and modularity improve when dependencies are unidirectional. Eunice's approach isn't limited to direct dependencies, but includes indirect dependencies as well. With Eunice you define an intended structure/architecture, it shows you dependencies that don't match, and you can further refine the definition or update your code to match.
name: eunice

scripts.all: npm run spellcheck && npm run lint && npm run build-prepare && npm run build-interactive && npm run test && npm run build && npm run build-remove-maps && npm run harness && npm run dogfooding
scripts.dogfooding: (cd dogfooding && rm -rf output && mkdir output && cd .. && node dist/bin.js --accept-license --directory-to-create-or-add-to-stacks-from=dogfooding --include-service-workers=true --ignore-path-pattern="(^|/)(\..*|dist|gh-pages|node_modules|output|test-cases|test-coverage)$" --infer-stacks --modify-stacks-file=dogfooding/modify-file-stacks.yaml --modify-stacks-key=type --modify-stacks-pattern=^file$ --output-base-file-name=index --output-directory-path=dogfooding/output --output-svg --output-yaml --package-names=call-with-process-standard-streams --package-names=dependency-and-structure --package-names=javascript-analyzer --package-names=processors --package-names=renderer --package-names=renderer-test-harness --package-names=run-tests-from-file-system --package-names=test-harnesses --package-prefix=eunice- --package-scope=devsnicket --directories=. --reverseFileContent=false --root-item-identifiers=javascript)
scripts.harness: (cd harness && rm -rf output && mkdir output && npx webpack -p --config webpack.config.js)
